Story behind Dance Theatre of Harlem's new work

Story behind Dance Theatre of Harlem's new work

Elizabeth Kramer, ekramer@courier-journal.com 11:10 a.m. EDT October 24, 2014

Dance Theatre of Harlem will perform Saturday at the Kentucky Center in Louisville.(Photo: Matthew Murphy)

Story Highlights

  • Dance Theatre of Harlem
  • What: Dance by choreographers Robert Garland ("New Bach"); George Balanchine ("Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux"); Ulysses Dove ("Dancing on the Front Porch of Heaven"); and Darrell Grand Moultrie ("Vessels").
  • When: 8 p.m. Saturday
  • Tickets: $22.50 to $75, Information: (502) 584-7777; www.kentuckycenter.org; dancetheatreofharlem.org
2 CONNECT 11 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Just this month, a dream came true for choreographer Darrell Grand Moultrie when Dance Theatre of Harlem performed a piece he had created for the company at Washington, D.C.'s Sidney Harman Hall.

"This is the company that comes from where I was born and raised," said Moultrie of the storied company started in 1949 by Arthur Mitchell, the first African-American principal dancer in George Balanchine's New York City Ballet, and Karel Shook.

On Saturday, his new dance "Vessels" — a piece with 10 dancers and four movements — makes its Louisville debut when Dance Theatre of Harlem performs at the Kentucky Center. The program also includes "New Bach" by company resident choreographer Robert Garland, George Balanchine's "Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux" and late choreographer Ulysses Dove's "Dancing on the Front Porch of Heaven."

Moultrie, 37, said a teacher encouraged him to take dance classes early on. Not long after, he began going to see all the performing arts he could in New York.

"From a young age, I started out being exposed to so many different things," he said recently. "I found it exciting to keep up with all of it and made sure that I just didn't go see ballet. I went to see Broadway shows, plays and musicals. When I was a student, I got student discounts. I knew ushers at State Theatre and the Met (who could get him into performances). That's how it worked out."

Choreographer Darrell Grand Moultrie. (Photo: Photo by Franklin Thompson. )

The chance to create a new work for Dance Theatre of Harlem came after Moultrie had chartered a strong career in dance — and one not limited to one form. His career includes work in the theater, ballet, modern and commercial dance worlds.

A graduate of LaGuardia High School of Music & Art and Performing Arts and The Juilliard School, he danced on Broadway in the musicals "Billy Elliot" and "Hairspray" and is now working with Tony Award-winning director Diane Paulus on choreography for the new musical "Witness Uganda." That show premiered in Boston in March and is preparing for its New York debut.

Moultrie has made a name for himself as a choreographer by creating dances for Colorado Ballet, Atlanta Ballet, San Francisco's Smuin Ballet and Ailey 2 (the junior company of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater). His commercial work has included choreographing some of the dance that was part of Beyoncé's 2013 "Mrs. Carter World Tour."

Choreographing for ballet, however, came slowly to this dancer who grew up studying modern, jazz and African dance before attending Juilliard where he studied ballet. Then, a company in Connecticut commissioned a small work from him. Later came requests from North Carolina Dance Theatre and Cincinnati Ballet. Still, he didn't yet feel quite secure in holding the title of choreographer in the ballet world or creating works on pointe shoes.

"I remember the first time a dancer walked into the room in Cincinnati, she said, 'Is this pointe or flat?' " he recalled. "In my head, I was hesitant to say it. Then I just said 'pointe' and that was my first work on pointe."

Since then he has created close to 40 works on pointe, some of which caught the eye of Virginia Johnson, who was a Dance Theatre of Harlem founding member and danced with the company for 28 years. She left the company after it closed in 2004, $2.4 million in debt, and went on to become founding editor of Pointe, a magazine covering the ballet world.

"There, I got the chance to travel around the country and see a number of ballet companies," she said in a recent telephone call from New York.

“I learned not to limit myself, I've learned if you can dream it, it can come true.”

Darrell Grand Moultrie, choreographer of Dance Theatre of Harlem

Among works by upcoming choreographers that caught her eye were those by Moultrie, whose pieces she saw danced by the Colorado Ballet, BalletMet Columbus in Ohio and Virginia's Richmond Ballet.

"Every time I saw his work, I thought this is a choreographer with such a vision of ballet as a dynamic and contemporary art form," she recalled.

Johnson returned to the company in 2009, as it erased its debt, to become the artistic director, a role that has enabled her to choose works for performances, including new works the company commissions.

Before Johnson's return, however, Moultrie had taught master classes at the Dance Theatre of Harlem School when the company was working to surmount its debt crisis. That was the initial connection. After Johnson become artistic director, she asked him to create duet or pas de deux pieces with former company members and Ashley Tuttle, who had danced with American Ballet Theatre and performed on Broadway in the musical "Movin' Out." For Moultrie, whose career includes a lot of teaching with companies and universities, a commission for the company wasn't guaranteed.

"Then she called me this past summer and said, 'I'd love to have you do work with the company,' " Moultrie said.

Moultrie's mind was turning, he said, with ideas about themes and music. He chose music by Italian composer Ezio Bosso and began thinking about how the company had inspired him when he was young.

"I thought about what it infused in me," said Moultrie, who discovered his title when he found the connection between the words "infuse" and "vessel." "I wanted to make sure this piece infused my artistic expression in the dancers and gave them different ways to express themselves them on stage."

A few days after "Vessels" made its world premiere, Johnson was full of praise.

"It's a beautiful, poetic work. He's really made something for these dancers that is just breathtaking," she said.

Moultrie's work not only fit with the company's mission of presenting the breadth and depth of classical ballet along with contemporary works, she said, but it also was a work by a young African-American choreographer in a field that is largely white. Other African-American choreographers on the Louisville concert program include Garland and Dove.

"Of course, we are about diversity," she said, "and presenting the finest work we can."

Dance Theatre of Harlem performing “Dancing on the Front Porch of Heaven,” choreographed by Ulysses Dove’s last work before he died of AIDS in 1996. (Photo: Photo by Rachel Neville )

She stressed that the company has a history of commissioning artists of different ethnicities and having a diverse company, which now numbers 18 dancers.

While Moultrie's name might not be widely recognized now, it could be in the future — especially with the anticipated New York opening of "Witness Uganda."

But no matter where Moultrie's work as a choreographer takes him, it's not the recognition that drives him. Working with dancers on both the professional and student levels is what he enjoys most.

One dancer, Aqura Lacey, who moved from Louisville to New York to attend Fordham University's program with the Alvin Ailey School, can attest to that. She worked with Moultrie in developing choreography for Beyoncé, but first met him when he came to choreograph a dance for a group of Ailey School students. She recalled he said he wanted them to get more from the work than the choreography and then delivered.

"He is able to work with dancers where they are," said Lacey, who danced with Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on the spring tour and recently with Jennifer Lopez in the charity event Fashion Rocks. "He can see what you can do and the possibility that you can do more than you can even imagine. He shows you how to use your technique in new ways and push it beyond where you saw limits."

Moultrie said he loves for dancers at any level to be challenged technically and artistically. He knows firsthand what a challenge can do. He got a challenge early on that set him on a life's journey.

"There was a teacher in third grade who paid for everything I did in the arts. She told me, 'You're going to do something really big. You're special. I'll pay for everything if you keep your grades up,' " he said. "There's nothing like it when you have people who believe in you."

Reporter Elizabeth Kramer can be reached at (502) 582-4682. Follow her on Twitter at @arts_bureau.
